thread.title: Church of England ministers could work beyond the age of 70 to ease recruitment crisis
thread.title_full: Church of England ministers could work beyond the age of 70 to ease recruitment crisis

author: Olivia Rudgard
title: Church of England ministers could work beyond the age of 70 to ease recruitment crisis
text:
Church of England ministers could work beyond the age of 70 to ease recruitment crisis The Archbishop of Canterbury will address the meeting Credit: Bethany Clarke/Getty Olivia Rudgard 12 February 2017 â€¢ 10:14pm 
S enior Church of England ministers look set to be allowed to work beyond 70, as its ruling body votes on the issue for the first time amid concerns about a shortage of clergy. 
The Anglican Church faces a recruitment crisis as hundreds of ministers are due to retire over the next decade and there is not enough younger staff to replace them. 
A vote on the new rules, due to take place on Tuesday at the Church of England synod, will come after the Archbishop of Canterbury, Justin Welby, addresses the meeting on Monday. 
Earlier this month, the Archbishop apologised to the alleged victims of John Smyth QC, who has been accused of abusing boys at a Christian holiday camp in the 1970s. If you want someone to be good at leadership, it's better to get them young so that by their 40s they're not just easing their way in, but are very experienced Reverend Dr David Hilborn 
O n Wednesday the synod, which is the governing body for the Church of England, will also vote on whether to "take note" of a controversial report produced by bishops last month about the Church's stance on gay marriage. 
The report has been criticised by both liberal and conservative wings of the church, and LGBT rights groups have urged members to reject it. 
Following the Archbishop's speech, and ahead of the vote, bishops will be questioned by members about the report and the church's position on gay rights and homophobia. 
The synod, which is the Church of England's governing body, meets to vote on new legislation and discuss issues affecting the Church. Credit: OJO Images Ltd / Alamy Stock Photo 
I n most cases, bishops, deans, archdeacons and residentiary canons currently face compulsory retirement at 70, but the new rules will allow them to continue for longer. 
Bishops and deans would have to get permission from an archbishop to continue, who would assess whether they would still be able to perform the role after age 70. 
Senior ministers would be able to continue in post to age 75, while those in junior roles could carry on for even longer. 
Last year, the Church said that 25pc of clergy were due to retire in the next five to 10 years, and not enough younger ministers were available to fill roles. What is the General Synod? 
R everend Dr David Hilborn, principal of Anglican training college St John's Nottingham, said that the lack of experienced clergy was partly caused by church policy. 
"The Church used to say to the youngest who applied that they should go away and get some life experience. 
"But if you want someone to be good at leadership, it's better to get them young so that by their 40s they're not just easing their way in, but are very experienced," he said. 
The measure has been introduced now because more older clergy are able and willing to continue past the age of 70. 
One quarter of clergy are in their 60s and the number of paid ministers has fallen from 8,006 in 2012 to 7,661 in 2015. 
Figures also show that 555 ministers left the clergy in 2015, while 457 joined - leaving a deficit of 98. 
A report published in September by the Church suggested that if clergy retired one year later than they currently do, this would help slow the decline. 
But it said the Church must also recruit more young ministers in order to halt the falling numbers. 
Dr Hilborn warned that the Church faces a struggle to train enough clergy to replace retirees. 
"We need to increase our vocations among younger ordinands by 50pc over the next five years or so, and that's a tall order," he said. 
If approved the new rules are due to come into force in July. The change would not affect the age at which clergy can collect their pensions, which will stay at 68. Follow Telegraph News
